page.title: 20NEWTOWN'S LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: Herbert the Chamberlain seems to have held land and a mill here in the 11th century, part of the estate may be traced to Ingoldfield Farm (613,143). Huntbourn, a purlieu, was described in the 12th century as being "along the highroad from Winton to Portesmues close by the Hall of Arred". The track can still be seen and evidence of a medieval farm (Harold's Hall) exists at Clays Copse. Hoegate Manor dating from the 16th century is built on a much older site. The farmhouse at Southend (17th C.)was a Jesuit centre and its chapel was demolished in 1959. Hoegate Farm is also old, and the farmer is the only person to retain grazing rights on Hoegate Common. The clay areas were more densely wooded than today and Newtown clay has been used at various times for brickmaking.
